abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Transport Sector
            Project (PST2) for Senegal were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory; the risk to development outcome was moderate;
            the Bank performance was satisfactory; and the Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: The benefits of comprehensive sector-wide
            institutional reforms. Attempts in earlier transport
            projects to reform transport institutions had limited
            success and at effectiveness the third quality at entry
            assessment (QEA3) expressed concern about the ambitious
            reform program. However, the project took on, among others,
            the objective of increasing private sector involvement in
            investment and management of the sector and achieved this
            objective fully. PST2 also provided ample resources to
            strengthen the institutions and brought about an improvement
            in the regulatory framework for transport institutions.
            Sustained commitment and partnership as a condition for
            effective implementation and completion of a complex
            project. The QEA3 noted the complexity of project design and
            the implementation risks attached to that. PST2 did face
            serious implementation difficulties and delays, but achieved
            its objectives, albeit with three extensions. Conditions for
            readiness for implementation are met. The project was
            initially not fully ready for implementation because of the
            marginally satisfactory preparation and the great complexity
            of its design. The overly complex design obscured the fact
            that conditions for reform, procurement, and privatization
            had not been put in place and that implementation and policy
            risks had not been adequately identified or mitigated. Not
            only effectiveness require two additional preparation
            missions, but it became clear early on that the preparation
            of the arrangements for institutional and regulatory reforms
            and for procurement and monitoring were not complete.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Second Transport Sector Project -
            proposed amendment to the Development Credit Agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
Restructuring of the Second Transport
            Sector Project is needed because of the impact of the
            significant changes introduced since the beginning of
            project activities, i.e., the Government introduced the
            following changes in the transport sector's strategy:
            a) Decision to build a new airport, when the project was
            initially supposed to support the management concession of
            the existing airport - Leopold Sedar Senghor International
            Airport; and, b) Decision to use resources from bonds on the
            local market for construction of a third berth of the
            container terminal in the port, whereas private financing
            was initially foreseen through Build Operate Transfer (BOT).
            In addition, the implementation of the Civil Aviation and
            Land Transport Administration components has been lagging;
            some measures have been under way for one year without being
            finalized, thereby preventing achievement of the
            components' objectives, and, two new executing agencies
            (Railway Concessionaire and Road Agency) were created, thus,
            there is a need to take into account the transfer of
            responsibilities to these agencies. Amendment to the
            Development Credit Agreement (DCA) is justified based on the
            need to: 1) reallocate funds; 2) take into account the new
            executing agencies - the Railway Concessionaire for the
            Railway Component and the Road Agency for the Road
            Maintenance Component; 3) close the two Project Agreements
            with the port authority and the former public railway
            company; 4) close the Port, the Land Transport
            Administration, and the Civil Aviation components; and, 5)
            extend the Credit closing date. These suggested changes are
            relevant to the project activities, and consistent with the
            project development objectives.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Transport Sector Project
            seeks to improve the supply and performance of transport
            infrastructure to create an environment for improved
            economic growth through expanded access and reduced
            transport costs. There are eleven project components. 1)
            Institutional building and reforms will support
            institutional strengthening measures in all other
            components. 2) Modernization of the Land Transport
            Department will support the reform of the testing systems
            for the processing of drivers' licenses, the full
            computerization of the Department, facility improvements,
            etc. 3) Sustainable and transparent financing of the road
            sub-sector will support the improvement of the management of
            the Road Fund. 4) Promotion of private sector involvement in
            sector will support the privatization of infrastructure and
            transport entities. 5) Environment will support measures to
            improve the environmental policy. 6) Road maintenance,
            rehabilitation, and construction will support the
            strengthening and maintenance of paved roads. 7) Railways
            will finance track renewals and related measures. 8) Civil
            aviation will support the rehabilitation of the main runway
            and facilities of the Dakar airport. 9) Modernization and
            development of the maritime and river transport sector will
            finance the expansion works for the container terminal at
            the port of Dakar. 10) Rural transport will support the
            design of a rural transport strategy. 11) Coordination will
            finance incremental recurrent costs, etc.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Second Transport Sector Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
Adverse effects on the environment will
            occur as a result of the Second Transport Sector Project
            implementation. The environmental assessment examines the
            impact on the environment caused by the construction of
            roads, railways, ports, and airports, envisaged to affect
            natural habitats due to deforestation, river flows
            disturbance, and landscape degradation, and, because of
            abusive exploitation of construction materials, and mining
            of phosphates and iron ore. Improper disposal of airplane
            parts may induce radioactive hazards, which will further
            threaten water, air, and noise pollution. These factors,
            will affect rural and urban environments, due to water/soil
            degradation, and, disturbances caused by gas emissions due
            to increased traffic, respectively. Mitigating measures
            re-enforce regulation of vehicle technical controls,
            including the use of lead-free gas, and safety measures.
            Hydrocarbon and oil spillage should be regulated in
            accordance to established exploration measures, and
            likewise, domestic and industrial wastes should be also
            monitored, and analyzed. Wastes should be disposed of in
            accordance with ecological trash collection, and disposal
            regulations. Adequate site selection will maximize social
            protection, as it will avoid disturbance on rural land, and
            relocation of affected populations, and, public hygiene will
            benefit from improved sanitation measures. A public
            awareness campaign is recommended.
